Folsomia candida is a species of springtail, a small, wingless arthropod belonging to the order Collembola. It is commonly known as the white springtail or the laboratory springtail.

F. candida is a soil-dwelling organism that is found in various terrestrial ecosystems, including forests, grasslands, and agricultural areas. It plays an important role in the decomposition of organic matter and nutrient cycling in the soil.

The species is characterized by its small size, typically ranging from 2 to 5 millimeters in length, and its white or pale-colored body. F. candida has a distinctive forked appendage called a furcula, which it uses to propel itself through the soil and escape from predators.

F. candida is widely used as a model organism in ecotoxicology and soil biology research. It is known for its resilience to various environmental stressors, such as changes in temperature, moisture, and exposure to pollutants. This makes it a valuable indicator species for assessing the health and quality of soil ecosystems.

Due to its importance in soil ecosystems and its use in scientific research, F. candida has been the subject of extensive study, contributing to our understanding of the ecology and biology of springtails and their role in terrestrial environments.
